newsitem.title: UK: "Break a leg" brings bad luck to Globe actor.
newsitem.headline: "Break a leg" brings bad luck to Globe actor.

text.p: The theatrical enjoinder to "break a leg" brought no luck to Shakespearian actor George Innes -- who broke one of his on stage on Tuesday night during the first public performance at London's newest theatre, the Globe.
Innes landed badly as he climbed down a rope ladder onto the stage at the Globe, a replica of the 16th century theatre where William Shakespeare's plays were first performed.
Actors traditionally say "break a leg" to one another before a performance instead of "good luck," which they consider unlucky.

The actor at first tried to carry on in his dual roles as Thurio and Antonio in Shakespeare's "Two Gentleman of Verona" but the performance had to be halted once it became clear he was badly injured, a spokeswoman for the theatre said.
"I don't know if anyone said "break a leg' to George, but it's curious, isn't it," the Globe's Artistic Director Mark Rylance told London's Evening Standard newspaper.
The reconstructed Globe will open officially in June 1997.
Tuesday night's performance was a dress rehearsal in front of more than 1,000 people on the eve of what the Globe is calling its "prologue season".
Innes' roles will be filled by other members of the cast, the spokeswoman said.
The 20-sided theatre, built from wood and thatch and open to the elements, has been built just yards (metres) from the site of the original Globe theatre which Shakespeare part-owned.
The original was destroyed by a fire set off by a stage cannon in 1613. It was rebuilt a year later, closed by the Puritans in 1642 and dismantled two years later.
